\documentclass{article}
\usepackage{tikz}
\usetikzlibrary{matrix, shapes, arrows, positioning,calc}
\usetikzlibrary{decorations.pathreplacing,decorations.pathmorphing}
\usetikzlibrary{decorations.markings}
\tikzset{%
  % Create a new command to draw a particular type of node
  % The argument is the "title" of the node. It is a string, but
  % should be a few words in length, a bit more than just the title.
  nodeC/.style args={#1, #2, #3}{%
    text width={5em},
    text centered,
    draw,
    line width = 2pt,
    rounded corners,
    text width={1.25cm},
    font=\footnotesize,
    text height = 0.5em,
    line width = 1pt,
    fill = #1, 
    node font=\bfseries,
    anchor = center
  },
  % For every picture environment, we'll need a key for the number of
  % columns (i.e. the width) and a key for the length of the vertical
  % line spacing. We'll call these keys 'cnum' and 'lsep', respectively.
  % For now, we'll set them to 8cm and 1pt, respectively.
  cnum/.code = {\global\def\numwidth{#1}},
  lsep/.code = {\global\def\lsep{#1}},
  % Now we can define the top node macro:
  %
  % The main arguments are the title, the tag, and the color.
  %
  % The main keys are: the width of the node, the length of the vertical
  % spacing between lines, and the color of the node. Note that these
  % values are specified as a pair of values: the first is the width, the
  % second is the length of the vertical spacing between lines.
  %
  % For the first argument, we'll need to specify the title. We'll make
  % it the height of the node. The title should be set in a separate macro,
  % since it will have to be different for every picture environment.
  %
  % The last argument is the color of the node.
  %
  % The style for the left and right arrow is very simple: just draw
  % the arrow as a path. We need to decorate it, because otherwise,
  % it will not be rendered. We'll decorate it with two different
  % decoration options, so it looks differently on the left and
  % the right side of the line. (The first option draws the decoration
  % on the line, the second option draws the decoration on the
  % decoration path.)
  % Thanks to the \drawnode macro, we can simply add the decoration
  % paths to the node text itself.
  leftarrow/.style = {decorate, decoration={snake, segment length=4pt}},
  rightarrow/.style = {decorate, decoration={snake, segment length=4pt,
    amplitude=1.5pt, pre length=2pt, post length=2pt}},
  % Now we can define the bottom node macro:
  %
  % The main arguments are the title, the tag, and the color. The main
  % keys are the width of the node, the length of the vertical spacing
  % between lines, and the color of the node. Note that these values are
  % specified as a pair of values: the first is the width, the second
  % is the length of the vertical spacing between lines.
  %
  % For the first argument, we'll need to specify the title. We'll make
  % it the height of the node. The title should be set in a separate macro,
  % since it will have to be different for every picture environment.
  %
  % The last argument is the color of the node.
  %
  % The style for the left and right arrow is very simple: just draw
  % the arrow as a path. We need to decorate it, because otherwise,
  % it will not be rendered. We'll decorate it with two different
  % decoration options, so it looks differently on the left and the
  % right side of the line. (The first option draws the decoration
  % on the line, the second option draws the decoration on the
  % decoration path.)
  bottomarrow/.style = {decorate, decoration={snake, segment length=4pt}},
  %
  % Now we can define the decoration macro:
  % (This code is probably missing, but I don't know it exactly how it works).
  decoration = {%
    markings,
    % The decoration is set to "markings", because otherwise it will
    % only decorate the line. It doesn't decorate the line itself. It
    % draws decoration paths.
    mark=between positions 0.15cm and 0.30cm step 0.15cm with {
      \draw[decorate, decoration={markings,mark=at position 0.25 with {
        \node[nodeC={blue,blue,fill=white},anchor=west] (a) {};
        \node[nodeC={red,red,fill=white},anchor=east] (b) {};
      } }] (0,0) -- (0,1);
    },
  }
}
